content.content: Associated Order(s): Large Joint Injection/Arthrocentesis: R knee
Post-Procedure Diagnose(s): Pain in right knee

Formatting of this note is different from the original.
POST OPERATIVE NOTE
Patient ID: Bob G Bilek is a 52 y.o. male
Chief Complaint: Follow-up of the Right Knee
HPI:
Prior surgery: Right open patellar tendon repair and removal of tibial tubercle ossicle on 09/21/2020.
Currently in a: no brace/sling
Pain is: not present
Currently taking: no medications
Wound problems: no
Current Weight Bearing Status: WBAT
Current Work status: full duty
Bob has returned to work and reports increased medial knee pain and stiffness. Denies significant instability. His strength continues to improve.
The following portions of the patient’s history were reviewed and updated as appropriate: allergies, current medication review, family history, social history and surgical history.
PHYSICAL EXAM:
Surgical incisions which are well healed. There is no erythema, no fluctuance, no drainage, no signs of infection.
Tenderness of the medial joint line
ROM
Flexion: 120
Extension: 0
*Crepitus with ROM
No ligamentous laxity
Quad strength: 5/5
Hamstring strength: 5/5
Distally the patient is neurovascularly intact. Normal pulse exam with 2+ distal pulses. Rapid cap refill.
ASSESSMENT:
Aftercare following surgery of the musculoskeletal system
Pain in right knee
1 year and 2 months s/p right knee open patellar tendon repair and removal of tibial tubercle ossicle. DOS 09/21/2020
- increased medial knee pain and stiffness since returning to work
POST OP PLAN:
There are no physical exam signs concerning for infection at this time
We will continue with the post operative rehabilitation protocol as instructed
WBAT
Working full duty
Updated x-rays today reveal just minimal/mild DJD.
Cortisone inj today due to increased pain and stiffness
MRI ordered r/o MMT
If only temporary relief with cortisone inj and MMT present without significant cartilage wear on MRI then consider scope PMM
Follow up - 3 weeks
Patient was seen and evaluated by physician assistant, Taylor Atkinson PA-C. The physician assistant was acting as sole provider.
VISIT ORDERS:
Orders Placed This Encounter
Large Joint Injection/Arthrocentesis: R knee
XR KNEE 4 VIEWS RIGHT
MRI knee right without contrast
US Guided Aspiration/Injection
Large Joint Injection/Arthrocentesis: R knee on 12/16/2021 3:00 PM
Indications: pain
Details: 22 G needle, ultrasound-guided anterolateral approach
Medications: 80 mg methylPREDNISolone acetate 40 MG/ML; 2 mL Naropin 5 MG/ML
Outcome: tolerated well, no immediate complications
Confirmed that the patient does not have history of prior adverse reactions, active infections, or relevant allergies. There was no effusion, erythema, or warmth, and the skin was clear. Post injection instructions we discussed and patient verbalized understanding.
KNEE ULTRASOUND
Under ultrasound guidance I visualized the lateral femoral condyle, the patellar tendon and the lateral tibial plateau. From the anterolateral approach the injection was given into the knee joint. The injection was visualized under ultrasound guidance.
Procedure, treatment alternatives, risks and benefits explained, specific risks discussed. Consent was given by the patient. Immediately prior to procedure a time out was called to verify the correct patient, procedure, equipment, support staff and site/side marked as required. Prep: Skin was prepped in normal sterile fashion. Topical anesthesia was achieved with ethyl chloride..
Electronically signed by Taylor at 09/24/2022 9:23 AM CDT

code.originalText: PR ARTHROCENTESIS ASPIR&/INJ MAJOR JT/BURSA W/US

item.caption: XR KNEE 4 VIEWS RIGHT - Final result (12/16/2021 3:26 PM CST)

paragraph.content: No fx or dislocation. Post op changes of patella s/p transosseous patellar
Mild medial and PF joint space narrowing. Lateral compartment well
